isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (WITH R-12 REFRIGERANT SYSTEM) - REFRIGERANT SYSTEM SERVICE

svcproc.title: SERVICING PRECAUTIONS
svcproc.para: R-12 and HFC-134A are classified as safe refrigerants; however, certain precautions must be observed to protect the parts involved and to prevent personal injury to service personnel.

warning.para: One of the most important measures to be taken while servicing air conditioning systems is constant and adequate eye protection. Safety goggles or other adequate eye protection must be worn. The temperature of liquid refrigerant is -15.7°C (-100°F). Serious injury or blindness will result from refrigerant contacting the eyes.

svcproc.para: If the refrigerant should contact the eyes, DO NOT rub them. Splash the eyes with cold water to gradually get the temperature above the freezing point. See a doctor immediately.
Should liquid refrigerant come in contact with the skin, the resulting injury should be treated the same as though the skin has been frostbitten or frozen.

warning.para: Do not smoke or allow any type of fire or flame in the immediate area while servicing the air conditioning system. Refrigerant is not combustible; however, in the presence of heat it changes to phosgene, a poisonous gas. Inhalation can cause death or serious injury.

Always use approved refrigerant recycling equipment when working with R-12 and HFC-134A. The refrigerant evaporates very quickly and may displace the oxygen surrounding the work area creating the hazard of suffocation or brain damage, especially in small or enclosed areas. Federal and State laws require that R-12 refrigerant be recovered and recycled to help protect the environment.

Never weld, solder, steam clean or use excessive heat on any of the air conditioning lines or equipment while the system is charged. Heat applied to any part will cause the pressure within the system to become excessive, which may result in an explosion and possible personal injury.

Be certain that pressurized refrigerant containers are not exposed to open flame or temperatures above 125°F (51°C). Do not discard empty refrigerant containers where they are likely to be subjected to the heat of trash burners, etc.; they may explode, resulting in personal injury or possible death.

Always use correct replacement refrigerant hoses. Do not use hoses other than those specified for the system being serviced. The use of improper hoses may cause a hose rupture, which may result in personal injury.
